tit.e: Kodai Sanjo (ancient castles built on the top of mountains)

sen.j: 古代山城（こだいさんじょう）は、飛鳥時代から奈良時代にかけて築かれた古代の山城のうち、朝鮮半島からの影響が指摘されるものを一般に指す。
sen.e: Archeologists and other experts generally refer to these castles as Kodai Sanjo castles which were ancient mountain castles built in the historical period from Asuka to Nara, and were also indicated in the influences from the Korean Peninsula.
Kodai Sanjo generally refers to ancient mountain castles built in the historical period from Asuka to Nara, which were influenced by the Korean Peninsula.

sen.e: Kodai Sanjo generally refers to ancient mountain castles built in the historical period from Asuka to Nara, which were influenced by the Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: ただし、この呼称は定義に未確定な部分があるので、考古学上は単に古代山城と呼ばれることが多い。
sen.e: However, since the origin in the form of this particular reference definition is uncertain, scholars in the study of archaeology usually settle on the term Kodai Sanjo for the mountain castles.

sen.j: 古代山城とは、西日本各地に古代に造られた山城の中で、「日本書紀」「続日本紀」になんらかの記載がある諸城およびその系統の山城。
sen.e: In order to described as a Kodai Sanjo, all mountain castles need to satisfy the following conditions; first, these mountain castles were built in several locations of western Japan during ancient time; among those ancient mountain castles, with in the castles were written statements in the "Nihon-shoki (the oldest chronicles of Japan)" or "Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued)"; and other lineage of the mountain castles.

Kodai Sanjo refers to castles which was built in several locations of western Japan in ancient times and be written some statements in the 'Nihon-shoki' (the oldest chronicles of Japan) or 'Shoku Nihongi' (Chronicle of Japan Continued), or other lineage of these mountain castles.

sen.j: 築城、改修、停廃等の記事が見られる。
sen.e: "Nihon-shoki" and "Shoku Nihongi" had written articles on castle construction, repairs, discontinues or abolitions of Kodai Sanjo castles.
Nihon-shoki' and 'Shoku Nihongi' contained articles on construction, repair, discontinuation or abolition of Kodai Sanjo castles.

sen.j: 特に663年の白村江の戦いの後、唐や新羅による侵攻に備え、天智天皇の命で各地に水城や山城が建設された。
sen.e: Especially in '663', after the Battle of Hakusukinoe, the Emperor Tenchi ordered the construction of the mizu shiro (castles on lakes or marshes erected for defensive reasons) castles and the mountain castles in preparation for an invasion by the Tang (a Chinese Dynasty) and the Silla (ancient Korean Kingdom).

Especially after the Battle of Hakusukinoe in 663, the Emperor Tenchi ordered the constructions of Mizushiro (castles on lakes or marshes erected for defensive reasons) and Yamashiro (castles built on the top of mountains or halfway up the mountains for defensive reasons) throughout the country in preparation for invasions by the Tang Dynasty and the Silla (ancient Korean Kingdom).

sen.e: Especially after the Battle of Hakusukinoe in 663, the Emperor Tenchi ordered the constructions of Mizushiro (castles on lakes or marshes erected for defensive reasons) and Yamashiro (castles built on the top of mountains or halfway up the mountains for defensive reasons) throughout the country in preparation for invasions by the Tang Dynasty and the Silla (ancient Korean Kingdom).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 日本書紀における長門城、大野城 (筑前国)、基肄城の記事に「亡命百済貴族が築城の指導に当たった」とある。
sen.e: In the Nihon-shoki, there was a statement which described the sort of, "Exiled nobles of Silla assignment to direct the building of castles," chronicled inside written articles about Nagato-jo Castle, Ono-jo Castle (Chikuzen Province), and Kii-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Nihon-shoki, it is written, 'The castle was built under the direction of exiled nobles of Kudara (Baekje, Paekche)' in the articles about Nagato-jo Castle, Ono-jo Castle (Chikuzen Province) and Kii-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 記号、誤訳、一部の訳文の構成を修正しました分割された原文を自然な日本語になるように修正しました

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらを含め築城年代・構造など共通性が見られるものを「古代山城」と称する。
sen.e: Including within the contents of the Nihon-sholki, was this point, some mountain castles shared common elements; such as, castle construction periods and architecture; and those castles which shared common points were referred to as "Kodai Sanjo."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Including this feature described above, castles referred to as 'Kodai Sanjo' had some points in common such as construction periods and their architecture, and so on.

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: このほか古代山城の中には怡土城のように中国城砦との関係が指摘されるものもある。
sen.e: Moreover, in the Kodai Sanjo castles, archeologists and other experts indicated that some castles had shared a relationship to the Chinese fortress, such as the Ito Castle.
Moreover, it is pointed out that some Kodai Sanjo castles, like Ito Castle, had a relationship with Chinese fortresses.

sen.j: また古代山城に類似した遺構として、神籠石（式山城）が総社市・鬼ノ城（1986年国の史跡に指定）など日本各地で16城発見されている。
sen.e: Additionally, archeologists and other experts indicated that the Kogo-ishi (rows of stones arranged on mountain slopes in Kyushu and Western Japan; also refer to the "Kogo-ishi style of mountain castle") castles shared ancient structural remnants similar to the Kodai Sanjo, and the sixteen Kogo-ishi castles including the Kinojo (ogre's castle) in Soja City (It was designated as a national historical site in '1986'); all were discovered in various locations throughout Japan.

sen.j: だが、これらは公的な記録がなく建造経緯などは不明なものが多い。
sen.e: However, there are no official documents or records on the Kogo-ishi castles confirming the process in castle construction; so, a great deal of the construction process remains to be undetermined.

sen.j: また、別系統の古代城郭に都城、国府城、関所、要害、水城、東北・北陸の城柵・鎮守府城、城館などがある。
sen.e: Further more, there were different systems of ancient castles: Miyakonojo (a capital or a city surrounded by castle walls), Kokufu-jo castle, sekisho (checking station), a fort, mizu-shiro (castles on lakes or marshes for defensive reasons), a josaku (an official defense site) and chinjufu (Pacification and Defense Headquarters) in Tohoku and Hokuriku regions, and Joukan (a castle styled architectural building).
